metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Git Ignore and .gitignore
Change Platform:
What is .gitignore?
The .gitignore file tells Git which files and folders to ignore (not track).
content.html: The .gitignore file tells Git which files and folders to ignore (not track).

content.text: This is useful for keeping log files, temporary files, build artifacts, or personal files out of your repository.
content.html: This is useful for keeping log files, temporary files, build artifacts, or personal files out of your repository.

content.text: The .gitignore file itself is tracked by Git, so everyone using the repository ignores the same files.
content.html: The .gitignore file itself is tracked by Git, so everyone using the repository ignores the same files.

content.text: When to Use .gitignore
Create a .gitignore File

content.code_html: touch .gitignore

content.text: Ignoring Folders
To ignore a folder and everything inside it, use a trailing slash:
content.html: To ignore a folder and everything inside it, use a trailing slash:

content.text: This ignores any folder named temp anywhere in your project.
content.html: This ignores any folder named temp anywhere in your project.

content.text: Wildcards & Patterns
Wildcards let you match many files or folders at once:
content.html: Wildcards let you match many files or folders at once:

content.code:
*.tmp      # all .tmp files
my?ile.txt # matches my1ile.txt, myAile.txt, etc.
log[0-9].txt # log1.txt, log2.txt, ... log9.txt
content.code_html:
*.tmp      # all .tmp files
my?ile.txt # matches my1ile.txt, myAile.txt, etc.
log[0-9].txt # log1.txt, log2.txt, ... log9.txt

content.text: Negation (!)
Use ! to not ignore something that would otherwise be ignored. This is called an exception:
content.html: Use ! to not ignore something that would otherwise be ignored. This is called an exception:

content.text: This ignores all .log files except important.log .
Comments and Blank Lines
Lines starting with # are comments and are ignored by Git. Blank lines are also ignored. Use comments to explain your rules:
content.html: Lines starting with # are comments and are ignored by Git. Blank lines are also ignored. Use comments to explain your rules:

content.code:
# Ignore log files
*.log

# Ignore temp folders
temp/
content.code_html:
# Ignore log files
*.log

# Ignore temp folders
temp/

content.text: Local & Personal Ignore Rules
If you want to ignore files only for yourself (not for everyone who uses the repository), add them to .git/info/exclude . This works just like .gitignore but is not shared.
content.html: If you want to ignore files only for yourself (not for everyone who uses the repository), add them to .git/info/exclude. This works just like .gitignore but is not shared.

content.text: Global .gitignore (User Level)
You can set up a global .gitignore file for all your projects. This is great for ignoring OS or editor files everywhere (like .DS_Store or Thumbs.db ):
content.html: You can set up a global .gitignore file for all your projects. This is great for ignoring OS or editor files everywhere (like .DS_Store or Thumbs.db):

content.code_html: git config --global core.excludesfile ~/.gitignore_global

content.text: Then add your patterns to ~/.gitignore_global .
How to Stop Tracking a File
If you add a file to .gitignore but Git is still tracking it, you need to tell Git to stop:
content.html: If you add a file to .gitignore but Git is still tracking it, you need to tell Git to stop:

content.code_html: git rm --cached filename.txt

content.text: This removes the file from the repository but keeps it on your computer. Next time you commit, Git will ignore it.
content.html: This removes the file from the repository but keeps it on your computer. Next time you commit, Git will ignore it.
